channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: Kabul airport could reopen for evacuation flights soon, says Dominic Raab
item.description: Kabul airport could reopen "in the near future" the UK's foreign secretary says, after talks in Qatar.

item.title: Kabul evacuation 'was planned and prepared for months', says Johnson
item.description: Boris Johnson says safe passage for those wanting to leave is a priority if the Taliban want engagement with the West.

item.title: Afghanistan: Councils prepare to offer homes to refugees
item.description: The UK has promised to resettle 20,000 Afghan refugees. Where will they live?

item.title: Brexit: Longer grace periods not a solution says Varadkar
item.description: The Irish deputy PM said grace period extensions for Irish Sea border checks "just puts things off".

item.title: Labour: Staff threaten strikes over potential job cuts
item.description: Two unions representing party workers say they would be prepared to take action if cuts are enforced.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon: SNP-Green deal 'a leap of faith'
item.description: Scotland's first minister says the SNP-Green deal could represent "a new and better way of doing politics".

item.title: Universal credit: Minister resists call to halt benefit cut
item.description: The work and pensions secretary rejects a call from UK politicians to maintain a £20 universal credit top up.

item.title: Afghan refugees: Those who worked for UK can stay permanently
item.description: Evacuees who worked for the British military and UK government will be given indefinite leave to remain.

item.title: Brexit: Rules for moving goods from NI to GB delayed
item.description: The rules govern which goods qualify for "unfettered access" when moving them from NI to GB.

item.title: James Brokenshire says his lung cancer has progressed
item.description: The former minister, who was diagnosed in 2018, says he is "keeping upbeat" ahead of new treatment.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK and Taliban in talks over further evacuations
item.description: A UK official is in Qatar for talks to secure the exit of both UK and Afghan nationals, No 10 says.

item.title: Afghanistan: Dominic Raab says UK must face new Taliban reality
item.description: The foreign secretary says the number of UK nationals still in Afghanistan is in the "low hundreds".

item.title: Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill tests positive for Covid-19
item.description: A meeting of the Stormont Executive on Wednesday to discuss restrictions has been postponed until next week.

item.title: Brexit: What next for the Northern Ireland Protocol?
item.description: NI's economy minister says there will be "real problems" if grace periods expire on 1 October.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: Scotland not a world leader on climate change
item.description: Speaking ahead of Glasgow's COP26, the activist says no country in the "global north" is doing enough.

item.title: Government plans to lift football standing ban
item.description: Some clubs will trial designated safe standing areas before the end of the season, the BBC understands.

item.title: The remarkable rise of the independent councillors
item.description: A quiet revolution is taking place in England and Wales as independent councillors challenge big parties.

item.title: Universal credit: Devolved governments join calls to keep £20 top-up
item.description: The devolved governments urge a rethink over plans to stop the extra £20-a-week payment in October.

item.title: Afghanistan: British ambassador home as last UK troops leave
item.description: Sir Laurie Bristow arrives on one of the last flights carrying UK personnel back from Afghanistan.

item.title: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon tests negative for Covid-19
item.description: The first minister had been self-isolating after being identified as a close contact of a Covid case.

item.title: Afghanistan: Ministers try to reassure MPs over missed evacuees
item.description: Senior members of the cabinet say the UK will continue to help people who want to leave Afghanistan.

item.title: Government to ban single-use plastic cutlery
item.description: Plastic plates and polystyrene cups will also be banned in England in what ministers call a "war on plastic".

item.title: Afghanistan: Every effort was made to destroy Kabul staff details, says Foreign Office
item.description: The UK says "every effort" was made to destroy sensitive papers when the embassy was evacuated.

item.title: Hire UK workers to drive lorries, minister tells firms
item.description: The business secretary rejects calls to relax immigration rules as companies struggle to fill vacancies.

item.title: Afghanistan: British nationals killed in Kabul airport attack
item.description: Two British nationals and the child of another are among the victims of Thursday's attack, the government says.

item.title: Afghanistan: Starmer calls for help for those left behind
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer says those left behind in the evacuation need an urgent plan to protect them.

item.title: COP26: Queen to attend climate conference in Glasgow
item.description: The monarch will join leaders including Pope Francis and US President Joe Biden at the UN event in November.

item.title: Brexit: Irish support for deal harming NI, says DUP leader
item.description: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson's claim comes after a meeting with Taoiseach Micheál Martin in Dublin.

item.title: No lasting homelessness fix after Covid scheme
item.description: A charity says fewer than one in four people helped by the Everyone In initiative now have permanent homes.

item.title: Covid travel: Seven locations moved to Covid travel green list
item.description: Canada and Denmark go on the green list while Thailand and Montenegro move to the UK red list.

item.title: Morrisons calls for action on lorry driver dearth
item.description: The supermarket chain joins others in the food and drink industry demanding a special help with visas.

item.title: Raab: We need to adjust to the new reality in Afghanistan
item.description: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab says the UK's commitment to Afghanistan remains, during a Qatar visit.

item.title: Afghanistan: Dominic Raab says intelligence told us Kabul was unlikely to fall this year
item.description: The UK foreign secretary said they expected a "steady deterioration" but the capital would be protected.

item.title: Dominic Raab: I'm not getting into 'fishing expedition' over holiday
item.description: The foreign secretary said he wouldn't add to the "fishing expedition" over his Crete trip during the Afghan crisis.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'A mission unlike anything we've seen in our lifetimes'
item.description: The final UK troops, diplomats and officials have left Kabul, Downing Street has confirmed.

item.title: Starmer: Urgent plan needed for those left in Afghanistan
item.description: The Labour leaders says "searing questions" await the government over its handling of the Afghan crisis.

item.title: Universal credit £20 drop: 'I'm used to hunger pains'
item.description: Under 25s are losing the biggest percentage of their income when the payments go down in October.

item.title: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater: Who are the new Green ministers?
item.description: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater are the first Green politicians to hold ministerial office in the UK.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey wants to target Tory heartlands
item.description: Smashing Tory dominance in the party's traditional areas is Liberal Democrats leader Ed Davey's plan. Can it work?

item.title: Levelling up: The seaside town debating what change is needed
item.description: As a report says levelling up plans must consider local views, people in Rhyl debate the changes needed.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who originally supported Trump's deal with the Taliban?
item.description: UK Defence Secretary Ben Wallace now calls it a "rotten" deal but supported it at the time.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: Woke: Compliment or criticism, it is now fuelling the culture wars
item.description: The surprising history of a term increasingly thrown around in UK political debate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Who is Dominic Raab?
item.description: A profile of the foreign secretary, as he comes under fire for his handling of the Afghanistan crisis.

item.title: Boris Johnson feels MPs' anger during Afghanistan debate
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.
